title-group.article-title: Is Acanthosis Nigricans a Reliable Indicator for Risk of Type 2 Diabetes in Obese Children and Adolescents?
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review

article-meta.aff: Harris County Hospital District, Pasadena, TXs, USA
School of Nursing, The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX, USA

author-notes.corresp: Cilymol Abraham, Harris County Hospital District, 3925 Fairmont Pky, Pasadena, TX 77504 , USA

fn.p: Cilymol Abraham, MSN, RN, CPNP, is a Pedatric Nurse Practictioner–Primary Care at Harris County Hospital District, Pasadena, TX , USA.
Cathy L. Rozmus, DSN, RN, is a professor and associate dean of University of Texas Health Science center at Houston School of Nursing, Houston, TX, USA.

abstract.p: Obesity and type 2 diabetes is becoming a major health problem affecting children and adolescents in the United States. This article reviews the current literature examining the association between the presence of acanthosis nigricans (AN) and risk for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in obese children and adolescents. Ethnicity, family history of diabetes, and emergence of obesity are contributing factors for development of hyperinsulinemia, and insulin resistance, and ensuing visible changes on skin which is known as the AN. The purpose of this review was to assess the validity of AN as an early indicator of T2DM. Nineteen articles that were published from 1994 to 2010 were included for this review and reported an association between AN, hyperinsulinemia, and hyperglycemia. Nurses and advanced nurse practitioners working with children and adolescents have a tremendous role in identifying the risk factors, counseling, role modeling, and referring them to available community resources to promote healthy living. Early initiatives focusing on lifestyle changes may halt the progress, chronicity, and burden of T2DM in children and adolescents.

body.p: Once thought to be a disease solely of adult population, type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is increasingly prevalent among children and adolescents. Reports from different areas in the United States and various parts of the world reveal that T2DM is becoming an epidemic, and the progression is closely associated with the epidemic of overweight and obesity (Hu, 2011; Meetoo, McGovern, & Safadi, 2007). Acanthosis Nigricans (AN) is reported to link with T2DM. In 2000, the American Diabetes Association established AN as a formal risk factor for development of T2DM (Miller, 2009).

AN is a hyperpigmented, usually brownish black papillomatous velvety thickening of the epidermis that primarily affects axillae, posterior neck fold, flexor skin surfaces, umbilicus, and occasionally mucosal surfaces (Jones & Ficca, 2007; Sinha & Sachwartz, 2007). The first documented case of AN was identified in 1889, in Germany, at Unna’s dermatology clinic. However, an association between AN and diabetes mellitus was first noted in 1976 (Miller, 2009; Sinha & Sachwartz, 2007). Studies have demonstrated an association of AN with hyperinsulinemia and T2DM, and the recent increase of T2DM among children and youth has heightened interest in children’s health, including screening children for AN as a risk factor for diabetes (Jones & Ficca, 2007; Whitaker, Davis, & Lauer, 2004). Although the American Diabetic Association (ADA) and American Academy of Pediatrics support guidelines for screening children, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) discourages screening children for AN in schools and communities because there is insufficient evidence to conclude AN is a risk factor for T2DM (Jones & Ficca, 2007).

The emergence of T2DM as an epidemic in many parts of the world has captured the attention of researchers who point out the need for investigating simple and cost-effective screening measures to identify individuals at risk for developing T2DM (Caceres, Teran, Rodriguez, & Medina, 2008; Hu, 2011; Narayan, Boyle, Thompson, Sorensen, & Williamson, 2003). Research on insulin resistance (IR), resultant insulinemia, and gradual exhaustion of the pancreas has established hyperinsulinemia as a marker for a predisposition to T2DM (Kong et al., 2010). However, laboratory testing for IR and insulin level are not cost effective for population screening nor a valuable tool in the early developent of the problem. Since the first report about AN in 1889, many dermatologists and endocrinologists have searched for relationships between AN and IR. Although some studies reported an association between AN and IR, to date no systematic review or quantitative meta-analysis has been done on this topic. The purpose of this systematic review is to evaluate the significance of AN as a reliable indicator for risk of type 2 diabetes in school-age obese children and adolescents.

sec.title: Problem Statement
sec.p: Consistent with the rise in childhood obesity, the epidemic of T2DM is mounting among children and adolescents globally. In the United States, 17% of children 2 to 19 years of age are obese with a body mass index (BMI) greater than the 95th percentile (Ogden, Carroll, Curtin, Lamb, & Flegal, 2010). Every 20 minutes, 60 Americans will be diagnosed with T2DM, and 9 Americans will die from diabetes-related complications. Annually, 3,700 new cases of T2DM are diagnosed in youth in the United States (Meyer & Hoffman, 2011). At present, 8% of the U.S. population (24 million) has been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. The incidence of T2DM is growing rapidly, and by the year 2030, 400 million people worldwide will be battling this disease (Campbell & Martin, 2009; Narayan et al., 2003). In 2007, the estimated expense for the treatment of diabetes in the United States was $174 billion and is expected to grow to more than $350 billion by 2025 (Campbell & Martin, 2009). T2DM accounts for 95% of diabetes cases, and it is closely associated with obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and hypercoagulation disorders (CDC, 2011). In children, as in adults, type 2 diabetes is caused by the combination of IR and β-cell secretory failure (Kaufman, 2005). Insulin is a hormone produced by the β-cell of the pancreas and assists the metabolization of carbohydrate, lipids, and proteins. IR is a reduction in the ability of tissue cells to use insulin, resulting in an increased production of insulin by the pancreas (hyperinsulinemia) to maintain the blood glucose level within normal limits.

T2DM usually follows a progression through a phase of altered glucose metabolism, resulting in a pre-diabetes state which includes IR, impaired fasting glucose, and impaired glucose tolerance. Even though this process may take decades in adults to progress to T2DM, in children and youth, this process appears to be accelerated and may take less than 2 years (Campbell & Martin, 2009). It is vital to screen and identify children and adolescents with IR and/or pre-diabetes for early intervention, to prevent, or to delay the progression to T2DM (Garnett et al., 2010).

Development of AN is influenced by high levels of insulin that stimulate epidermal keratocyte and dermal fibroblast via insulin-like growth factor receptors. This keratocyte proliferation leads to skin changes like papillomatosis and hyperkeratosis (Grandhe, Bhansali, Dogra, & Kumar, 2004). Several studies have associated AN with increased IR and hyperinsulinemia (Hirschler, Aranda, Oneto, Gonzalez, & Jadzinsky, 2002). There are familial and syndromic forms of AN caused by malignancies and administration of medications such as insulin. There is no sex preference for AN, but it is much more common in people with darker skin pigmentation (Sinha & Sachwartz, 2007). Health care workers usually diagnose AN clinically by inspecting the skin (Sinha & Sachwartz, 2007). AN is identified in many children with IR and, because of the association of IR and type 2 diabetes, AN was proposed as an IR marker and as an independent risk factor for T2DM (Brickman, Huang, Silverman, & Metzger, 2010; Miller, 2009).

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: A systematic review was conducted by searching electronic databases using Internet search engines: Pub Med, Pub Med Central, CINAHL, MEDLINE, COCHRANE Database, SCOPUS, and DynaMed. Keywords for the review included Acanthosis Nigricans, children, adolescents, youth, type 2 diabetes mellitus, noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM), obesity, overweight, IR, hyperinsulinemia, diabetic screening, and markers of diabetes. Studies published on the relationship between T2DM and AN since 1986 were reviewed. Additional relevant studies were identified by reviewing reference lists of published studies. A literature search using a list of key words identified 52 potential articles for the review.

sec.title: Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria for Study Selection of Systematic Review

list-item.p: Research studies on children and adolescents between the ages of 3 and 19 years with clinically identified AN.
Studies that report levels of significance (p value or confidence interval).
Studies involving adults and children, if minimum 10% study populations were children between the ages of 3 and 19.

sec.title: Exclusion criteria

list-item.p: Studies with no reports of methodological research process and statistical analysis.
Studies done exclusively on an adult population.
Studies published in languages other than English, even though the abstract was published in English.
Research involving AN in association to medical conditions, such as malignancy, and secondary obesity caused by endocrine and genetic disorders, such as Prader-Willi syndrome.

sec.p: The suitability of the material was assessed based on relevance to the review question. Studies obtained via literature search were first evaluated by the title of the study and then according to the abstract. Twelve clinical reviews were excluded as they were not research based. Eight studies lacking methodological research process and statistical analysis also were excluded. Four studies were excluded as the population of study was mixed and clear delineation about the data collection method was missing. Nineteen articles published from 1994 to 2010 were included for this review. Out of the 19 studies, 16 of them were exclusively on the population of children, and 3 of them had participants 3 to 40 years. The studies included for this systematic review are displayed in Table 1.

tr.td: Stuart, Smith, Gilkson, Shaheb, and Stahn, (1994), United States
Evaluate the validity of Acanthosis Nigricans (AN) among Native Americans as an indicator of high diabetes risk
1,217 children 3 to 19 years of age
Cross-sectional study
AN on neck using posters as visual tools, Fasting insulin level, body mass index (BMI)

19% had AN, prevalence of AN increased with ↑BMI. AN+ group had significantly higher level of insulin. AN (on neck) is a readily visible marker of endogenous hyperinsulinemia and thus, a marker for developing T2DM.
Bent et al. (1998), United States
Assess the usefulness of screening school age children for AN as an early clinical marker of increased risk for type 2 diabetes
308 sixth grade students from two schools in New Mexico
Pilot study screening
AN on neck. using posters of AN, Ethnicity

AN is an early clinical proxy marker of increased risk of T2DM. Out of 308 participants 104, AN+. Highest prevalence among American Indian 53.6%. Hispanic 40.7% Asian/Pacific Islander 33.3%, Non-Hispanic White 7.8%
Mukhtar, Cleverley, Voorhees, and McGarth, (2001), United States
To determine the association of AN with hyperinsulinemia is independent of obesity and other variables
675 sixth, seventh & eighth grade students in New Mexico
Screening for AN, Survey-Questionnaire Data analyzed by descriptive analytic methods
AN screening on neck, Fasting Insulin, & FBS, age, gender, ethnicity, family history of DM nutrition status, and physical activity data

AN + group has higher fasting insulin level. AN prevalence varied with ethnicity. Native Americans 38.6%, Hispanic 19.7%, Non-Hispanic White 4.7%, no gender difference noted, positive correlation with AN and obesity+ (49.2%), and family history of DM (41%). AN alone is a positive predictor for hyperinsulinemia 39.4%, combined with obesity it is 47.2%
Stoddart, Blevins, Lee, Wang, and Blackett, (2002), United States
To determine the prevalence of AN to hyperinsulinemia compared with other risk factors for T2DM in American Indian children
2,205 Cherokee Indian children and adults from 5 to 40 years
A cross-sectional study using a random sample, correlation analysis.
Visual screening for AN, BMI, BP, Fasting insulin level, lipids, FBS
AN is an independent marker for hyper insulinemia and a predictor of T2DM. Prevalence increased with age and degree of Indian heritage and higher in female, and with ↑BMI and family history of T2DM.
Hirschler, Aranda, Oneto, Gonzalez, and Jadzinsky, (2002), Argentina
To evaluate the significance of AN a marker of IR in obese children
1250 Hispanic students (12.4 ± 1.4 years)
Randomized cross-sectional study, multivariate analysis
Birth WT, FMH-obesity and T2DM, BMI, AN, BP, and Tanner stage. OGTT, Insulin level, lipid profile .
The presence of AN showed a positive correlation with BMI (55.4%) There were higher fasting insulin and HOMA-IR in AN + group
Yamazaki, Ito, and Yoshida, (2003), Japan
To determine whether AN is a reliable cutaneous marker of IR and T2DM in obese Japanese children
439 obese Japanese children Mean age 10.1 years
Retrospective comparative study
Visual screening for AN, fasting plasma insulin, FBS, OGTT

AN is a reliable cutaneous marker of IR and T2DM. Children with AN showed more impaired glucose tolerance and T2DM compared with those without AN, and the mean plasma insulin concentration was significantly correlated with presence of AN
Kobaissi, Weigensberg, Ball, Cruz, Shaibi, and Goran, (2004), United States
To investigate in a Hispanic population, the relationship between AN and severity of AN and insulin sensitivity independent of obesity
131 Hispanic overweight children between 8 and 13 years
Longitudinal study, multivariate linear regression analysis
Visual scoring of AN (0–4 scale), BMI, IVGTT

AN is an independent risk factor for IR, in overweight Hispanic children at risk for T2DM. Body adiposity is the primary determinant of insulin sensitivity; AN grading has no significant usefulness. 73% participants had AN *Small sample size, study limited only to Hispanic population
Drobac, Brickman, Smith, and Binns, (2004), United States
To describe the application of a T2DM screening protocol in an urban pediatric clinic
997 children between 10 and 18 years of age
Retrospective chart review Data analyzed using chi-square and Fisher’s exact test
BMI, FMH-diabetes, ethnicity, BP, FBS/OGTT,

AN, a strong driving factor in identification and screening for T2DM. (93%).AN provided a strong visual cue for prompt diabetic screening using ADA protocol. 84% of whom screening ordered were overweight. *Missing family history of T2DM in many charts.* Overrepresentation of Hispanic population predominantly low-income Mexican American
(Whitaker, Davis, and Lauer, 2004), United States
To determine whether a screening program for T2DM is warranted in seventh grade population and to increase health care providers’ awareness of the need for screening
307 seventh grade students 12–14 years of age
A descriptive nonexperimental design, survey using a questionnaire
Visual scoring of AN, BMI, BP, family history of DM, age, ethnicity, gender
Findings are supportive of the screening seventh grade students for T2DM. Family history of diabetes correlated with presence of AN. *No laboratory tests done to determine IR
Miura et al. (2006), United States
To clarify the clinical significance of AN in obese Japanese children and adolescents
70 children between 5 and 19 years
A descriptive nonexperimental design. Data analysis done using the Mann–Whitney U test and logistic regression
Visual scoring of AN, BMI, FBS, insulin level genetic markers for T2DM
AN is a useful clinical marker for the severity of obesity and has close association with genetic markers for T2DM and obesity (Gly16 and Arg64) *Small sample size
Kong et al. (2007), United States
To determine the association of AN with T2DM risk factors and disease in children
96 children aged 7 -19 years (total population 483 adults and children)
Cross-sectional study. Data collected by chart review and interview. Data analyzed using chi-square test and Fisher’s exact test
Visual scoring of AN, graded using photographs, BMI, FMH-DM in first- or second-degree relatives

AN+ with increased risk for T2DM. AN is an independent risk factor for development of T2DM. AN + identify those patient with multiple risk for T2DM. 69% had family history of DM *Overrepresentation of Hispanic and American Indian. *No laboratory test done to determine the effect of dyslipidemia on AN
Silva, Miranda, Chacra, and Dib (2007), Brazil
To evaluate the IR β-cell function, and glucose tolerance in Brazilian adolescents with obesity or risk factors for T2DM
119 Adolescents 10–19 years of age
A descriptive cross-sectional study. Data analyzed using ANOVA & Spearman’s correlation
BMI, AN BP, FBS, & OGTT, lipid profile
Among obese group, 67% had AN, they also had High IR. Adolescents with + AN, have ↑ IR and have two more risk factors for TDM *Positive for family history of DM
Guran, Turan, Akcay, and Bereket (2007), Turkey
To determine the clinical and laboratory difference in obese children with AN and with out AN
160 Obese children (10.4–3.3 years)
A cross-sectional study
Visual scoring of AN, BMI, FBS, fasting and PM insulin level, HOMA-IR,
AN is a useful clinical indicator for T2DM. Obese children with AN shows hyperinsulinemia, and IR (HOMA-IR). AN is an important predictor of IR. Prevalence of AN increases with↑ in weight.
Chang et al. (2008), South Korea
To identify the cutoffs for anthropometric indices of adiposity for development of AN in Asian preadolescent school children.
4033 fifth grade students
A cross-sectional study. Data analyzed using chi-square test and Fisher’s exact test
Visual scoring of AN, BMI, percentage weight for height (PWH), percentage body fat (PBF)
AN has a good correlation with level of adiposity. Presence of AN is significant in the development of T2DM. AN+ in boys with BMI >22.2 kg/m2, and in girls with BMI >21.2 kg/m2
Caceres, Teran, Rodriguez, and Medina (2008), Bolivia
The primary objective was to determine the association between IR and metabolic syndrome and secondary objective was determining the relation of AN and IR.
61 obese children aged between 5 and 18 years
A descriptive cross-sectional study. Data analyzed by Fisher's exact test
Visual scoring of AN, BMI, OGTT, Lipid Panel, FBS, HOMA-IR, waist–hip ratio (WHR).
IR was significant (39.4%) among children with obesity. Even though this study showed strong correlation between IR and high BP and high TGL. AN + in 70% of patients with IR. *Small sample size
Ice, Murphy, and Neal (2009), United States
To analyze the prevalence of metabolic syndrome in a large sample of children with AN
676 fifth grade students Age 10.83±0.72
Cross-sectional screening
AN, BMI, FBS, IR, lipid profile BP
The presence of AN and morbid obesity are indicators of metabolic syndrome. 49% had three risk factors for metabolic syndrome including IR, high BMI, elevated BP, or dyslipidemia.
Peterson, Sheffer, Long Roth, Bennett, and Lloyd (2010), United States
Noninvasive screening for risk factors of T2DM in young, rural, Caucasian children
299 Students KG–eighth grade 4–14 years of age
Descriptive, cross-sectional study.
Family history of DM, high BMI for age/sex, racial/ethnic background, hypertension, and AN

Only 2.6% young, rural, Caucasian participants had signs of AN. This is low compared to prevalence of AN among minorities like Native Americans (38.6%). Presence of AN was not identified as an indicator for T2DM
Brickman, Huang, Silverman, and Metzger (2010) United States
To determine whether AN identifies youth at risk for metabolic abnormalities including IR
287 children, 11.7 ± 1.8 yrs.
Descriptive, cross-sectional study, using survey questions prevalence study.
AN, BMI, BP, OGTT
This study shows that AN is an indicator of significant IR and more than 1 in 4 will have evidence of abnormal glucose homeostasis that is supportive of development of T2DM
Kong et al. (2010), United States
To determine high prevalence of AN in other practices other than Southwestern practices as found in an earlier study. To explore the association of AN and IR, fasting hyperglycemia, and lipid levels
143 children between 7 and 19 years of age from a large population of children and adult population between 7 and 65 years presenting for primary care
A multicenter cross-sectional study, matched subsample with no AN
AN, BMI, BP, family history of DM, dyslipidemia, hypertension, ethnicity, IR (HOMA)

High prevalence of AN noted across all population group, but highest among minority population AN equally prevalent in adult and children, AN is an independent risk factor for T2DM. AN shows strong association with high fasting insulin level and IR. *clinicians were trained on identification of AN

fn.p: Notes: ANOVA = analysis of varaince; ADA = American Diabetic Association; BP = blood pressure; IR, insulin resistance; T2DM, type 2 diabetes mellitus.; TGL = Triglyceride; HOMA = Homeostasis Model Assessment; OGTT = Oral Glucose Tolerance Test; FBS = Fasting Blood Sugar; FMH = Family Medical History

sec.title: Data Extraction and Synthesis
sec.p: The studies that met the inclusion criteria were critically reviewed to assess validity. The summary of the studies are provided in Table 1. The majority of the studies were descriptive cross-sectional studies. The tools of data collection used by the researchers were mostly screening, surveys, and questionnaires. Some studies used random selection of subjects to increase validity. The sample size varied widely from 61 subjects to 2,205 subjects. Most of the studies identified were conducted in the United States (13 studies), two of them in Japan, one each in Turkey, Bolivia, Argentina, Korea, and Brazil.

As the purpose of the study was to assess the significance of AN as an early marker for T2DM, findings concerning AN and fasting blood glucose, fasting insulin level, and IR were extracted from each study. Findings regarding cofactors such as age, obesity, and ethnicity also were compiled.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: Many factors contribute to the development of T2DM. Race and ethnicity, family history of diabetes, and presence of obesity are the three most significant determining factors that have shown an association with AN.

sec.title: Ethnicity
sec.p: There is considerable difference in the development of AN as well as T2DM in various ethnic groups. Native American children have a higher rate of T2DM than children of other ethnicities (Drobac, Brickman, Smith, & Binns, 2004; Stoddart, Blevins, Lee, Wang, & Blackett, 2002). Mexican American and African American children also are at increased risk (Stuart, Smith, Gilkison, Shaheb, & Stahn, 1994). The Cherokee diabetes study reported an overall high prevalence of AN among Native Americans (Stoddart et al., 2002). These findings were supported by studies done in New Mexico by Mukhtar, Cleverly, Voorhees, and McGarth (2001) and the PRIME Net study conducted in 2010 by Kong et al. (2010), in which the prevalence of AN among Native Americans and Hispanics was high compared to non-Hispanic children. The researchers found that the severity of AN and hyperinsulinemia increased with age and degree of Indian heritage. The risk for T2DM was significantly higher among Native Americans when compared to non-Hispanic White subjects, as evidenced by an increased level of IR and high level of fasting insulin level (Kong et al., 2010; Mukhtar, Cleverly, Voorhees, & McGarth, 2001; Stuart et al., 1994). The reported prevelance of AN is low among Caucasians (Kong et al., 2007; Mukhtar et al., 2001; Peterson, Sheffer, Long-Roth, Bennett, & Lloyd, 2010). This low prevelance may be attributed to the fact that inexperienced clinicians have an increased difficulty in identifying AN in individuals with fair skin compared to darker colored individuals (Kong et al., 2010). However, several studies have found ANto be a driving factor in the identification and screening for T2DM in ethnic minorities (Brickman et al., 2010; Drobac et al., 2004; Kong et al., 2007, 2010; Whitaker et al., 2004).

sec.title: Obesity
sec.p: There are several contributing risk factors for the development of Type 2 DM in children and adolescents. The risk for T2DM is greatly increased among individuals who are obese (BMI >95th percentile) and also positive for AN. Out of 19 studies reviewed, 17 showed a correlation of obesity to the presence of AN (Brickman et al., 2010; Chang et al., 2008; Grandhe et al., 2004; Guran, Turan, Akcay, & Bereket, 2008; Hirschler et al., 2002; Ice, Murphy, & Neal, 2009; Kaufman, 2005; Kobaissi et al., 2004; Kong et al., 2007, 2010; Le, Scheen, & Pierard, 2004; Miura et al., 2006; Peterson et al., 2010; Rodbard, 2008; Silva, Miranda, Chacra, & Dib, 2007; Whitaker et al., 2004). The severity of AN that develops in an obese individual correlates positively with the degree of excess weight and the level of IR of the individual (Jones & Ficca, 2007). An obese individual with AN exhibits a markedly higher fasting insulin level than obese individuals without AN (Kobaissi et al., 2004; Kong et al., 2010). According to Meetoo, McGovern, and Safadi (2007), 90% of T2DM is associated with obesity. Among obese children, progressive hyperinsulinemia leads to rapid progression of AN during puberty. In addition to obesity, the presence of AN is one of the first signs that indicate IR and risk for developing T2DM. IR is a major underlying cause of AN, and the severity of AN may parallel the degree of IR (Brickman et al., 2010; Sinha & Sachwartz, 2007).

Review of these studies suggests that AN is a marker of hyperinsulinemia and IR in individuals with obesity (Hirschler et al., 2002). Being obese promotes IR resulting in a high risk of developing T2DM (Guran et al., 2008; Kong et al., 2010; Le et al., 2004). Researchers identified AN even in overweight children who are not classified as obese although the presence and extent of AN is in proportion to the BMI (Chang et al., 2008).

sec.title: Family History
sec.p: Contributing factors such as family history of T2DM, dyslipidemia, and hypertension increase the risk of T2DM in children with obesity and AN (Kong et al., 2010; Mukhtar et al., 2001; Silva et al., 2007; Stoddart et al., 2002; Whitaker et al., 2004). A study on Turkish Caucasian children identified family history of T2DM in first- or second-degree relatives as the most prevalent risk factors for development of T2DM in an obese or overweight child (Whitaker et al., 2004). Several studies report that family history of diabetes has more correlation with T2DM than obesity (Kong et al., 2010; Miura et al., 2006; Mukhtar et al., 2001; Peterson et al., 2010; Stoddart et al., 2002; Whitaker et al., 2004).

sec.title: AN and T2DM
sec.p: The presence and statistical significance of AN in relation to T2DM was reviewed (see Table.1). Among all the reviewed studies, 16 out of the 19 studies identified AN as a marker of IR (Brickman et al., 2010; Guran et al., 2008; Kong et al., 2007, 2010; Miura et al., 2006; Silva et al., 2007; Stuart et al., 1994; Whitaker et al., 2004; Yamazaki, Ito, & Yoshida, 2003). All of these 16 studies reported a statistically significant higher level of fasting insulin in patients with AN. Studies conducted by Hirschler, Aranda, Oneto, Gonzalez, and Jadzinsky (2002), and Stoddart, Blevins, Lee, Wang, and Blackett (2002) reported an association between AN and obesity. However, the authors did not provide any data about the statistical significance. The study conducted by Kobaissi et al. (2004) reports that AN is an independent risk factor for IR in overweight Hispanic children at risk for T2DM. However, according to the researchers, body adiposity is the primary determinant of insulin sensitivity and AN grading has no significant clinical usefulness. Five of the 6 studies that measured IR using Homeostasis Model Assessment of Insulin Resistance (HOMA-IR) associated AN with IR and a higher prevalence of T2DM in children and adolescents (Bent et al., 1998; Hirschler et al., 2002).

A retrospective comparative study conducted on 439 obese Japanese children found that fasting blood glucose and insulin level are significantly elevated in children with AN, compared to children without AN (Yamazaki et al., 2003). This finding is supported by reports from several other studies conducted in the United States (Brickman et al., 2010; Ice et al., 2009; Stoddart et al., 2002) and in Turkey (Guran et al., 2008).

A study on Brazilian adolescents with obesity reported that adolescents with two or more risk factors have higher IR (Silva et al., 2007). The Miura et al. (2006) study on Japanese children and adolescents reported a statistically significant difference in fasting immunoreactive insulin (IRI) and IR (HOMA-R) in obese children with AN. Mukhtar et al. (2001) reported that AN alone had a positive predictive value of 39.4% for hyperinsulinemia. Combined with obesity, AN substantially increased the predictive value for detecting children with hyperinsulinemia (47.2%). The findings from Drobac et al. (2004) supported the predictability of AN as a marker of IR and risk for T2DM. Among Hispanic and Native American children with obesity and a family history of diabetes, presence of AN is a strong visual cue (Kobaissi et al., 2004). However, even though AN is an independent risk factor for IR and development of T2DM in overweight Hispanic children, body adiposity is the primary determinant of insulin sensitivity. The prevalence of AN is less likely to be present in obese young Caucasians as a marker of T2DM (Kong et al., 2010).

The PRIME Net study analyzed the relationship between the presence of AN and the number of risk factors for T2DM and found that the greater the number of risk factors, the higher the prevalence of AN (Kong et al., 2010). All 19 studies identified the presence of AN in children and adolescents as a risk factor for T2DM. Evidence supports AN as a reliable marker for glucose intolerance and hyperinsulinemia. IR and β-cell dysfunction are pathogenic components of T2DM. The association of AN with obesity increases reliability in predicting future development of T2DM. This review supported the previous findings on the role of ethnicity as a major risk factor for the development of T2DM. Native Americans, Hispanics, and African American children have a higher risk for T2DM when compared to non-Hispanic White children.

Together the findings from this review delineate the emerging importance of screening all obese children and adolescents with AN for T2DM. The presence of AN, a precursor to diabetes, is an early marker that when recognized provides the opportunity for early implementation of preventive measures, such as recommendations for increased physical activites and healthy eating.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: The studies included in this systematic review have several identified strengths and limitations. Out of 19 studies, 14 were cross-sectional studies using children and adolescents in school settings and primary care clinics (Brickman et al., 2010; Caceres et al., 2008; Chang et al., 2008; Guran, Turan, Akcay, & Bereket, 2007; Ice et al., 2009; Kobaissi et al., 2004; Kong et al., 2007, 2010; Peterson et al., 2010; Silva et al., 2007; Stoddart et al., 2002; Stuart et al., 1994; Yamazaki et al., 2003) and 5 studies were retrospective nonexperimental studies using chart review from primary clinics (Bent et al., 1998; Drobac et al., 2004; Miura et al., 2006; Mukhtar et al., 2001; Whitaker et al., 2004). The studies included for review were conducted at various locations over the past two decades and sample size varied widely (61–2,205 children between 3 and 19 years of age). Limitations to the study include that they were over represented by Native American and Hispanic children. The effects of confounding factors on collected data cannot be excluded. There is a possibility of underestimating risk factors because the studies were based on risk factors that had been documented by the medical provider in the medical record. Family history was missing in several studies.

Moreover, currently there is no standard defintion or tool for AN screening (CDC, 2011). Out of 19 studies, only 4 studies included some details about the tools used, such as pictures or photographs for the identification, comparison, and grading of AN (Guran et al., 2007; Kong et al., 2010; Stoddart et al., 2002; Stuart et al., 1994). Moreover clinicians had difficulty in diagnosing AN in fair skinned persons, therefore classification bias may have resulted in underestimation of AN among non-Hispanic White children (Kong et al., 2010). Studies that recruited participants on a voluntary basis may have sampling bias as participants with a family history of diabetes may have been more likely to be enrolled for the study. Most of the studies were conducted with Native Americans, African Americans, or Hispanics. There were only a few studies on mixed populations. Therefore, the findings are generalizable only to the specific group of people in the specific region. This systematic review is based on published studies and, therefore, subject to publication bias. Therefore, the possibility of an overrepresentation of studies that report a positive relationship with AN and T2DM cannot be expelled.

sec.title: Implication for Practice
sec.p: The consistency of the correlation of AN with T2DM and the overall high prevalence of AN in all the studies emphasize the generalizability of the findings. This review also supports the correlation of AN with the presence of hyperinsulinemia and IR in children with obesity (Brickman et al., 2010; Chang et al., 2008; Grandhe et al., 2004; Guran et al., 2008; Hirschler et al., 2002; Ice et al., 2009; Kaufman, 2005; Kobaissi et al., 2004; Kong et al., 2010; Le et al., 2004; Miura et al., 2006; Peterson et al., 2010; Rodbard, 2008; Silva et al., 2007). The current magnitude of the increase in prevalence of obesity-related diabetes, coupled with future morbidity and mortality associated with diabetic complications, heralds the need for early identification and control of this epidemic, especially among the young population (Jones & Ficca, 2007; Meetoo et al., 2007). Appropriate screening for all children at risk for T2DM will result in early identification and implementation of preventive measures and a better likelihood of glycemic control (Rodbard, 2008). Screening for AN among Native Americans, Hispanics, and African American children who are at high risk for developing T2DM has important implications for early identification and intervention that can prevent or delay the progression to T2DM. The most effective treatment for AN is weight loss to correct the underlying condition of hyperinsulinemia and dyslipidemia. In 2005, the ADA and the American Academy of Pediatrics recommended screening school age children ≥10 years old with a BMI >85th percentile, who also have substantial risk factors such as family history or signs of IR (Jones & Ficca, 2007). The CDC does not recommend AN screening but recommends primary preventive approaches that focus on nutrition and physical activity to control overweight and obesity (CDC, 2011; Jones & Ficca, 2007).

Even though currently there is no unanimous agreement for AN screening nationally, many clinicians believe that it is important to utilize this screening opportunity in order to educate the public about ADA recommendations and refer children who are at risk for further evaluation to prevent development of future health problems (Jones & Ficca, 2007; University of Texas Pan American Border Health Office, 2009). Early identification and intervention with dietary modification and exercise to achieve a healthy weight and endocrinologic hormonal balance prevent development of T2DM and other associated complications. If AN is diagnosed clinically, further diagnostic tests including fasting serum insulin, glucose levels, and fasting lipid profile are warranted. Advanced nurse practitioners providing primary care services and those who provide services at school-based clinics have a tremendous role as team leaders to work with children, parents, school nurses, dietitions, social workers, and diabetic specialists.

sec.title: Implication for Future Research
sec.p: T2DM is a major health care issue escalating among children and adolescents. This systematic review supports a strong association of AN and future predicability of T2DM. However studies on the validity and reliability of the currently avaliable scale for assessment of AN are limited. Although, the current quantitative scale is highly specific to the Hispanic population, its validity and sensitivity are not evaluated among other ethnic groups (Burke, Hale, Hazuda, & Stern, 1999). The sensitivity and predictability of AN has shown a parallel increase with increase in BMI. However, it will be valuable to conduct studies to evaluate the usefulness of AN in quantitatively predicting the progression of T2DM. Future areas of research also include ethnic-specific studies especially on non-Hispanic White children as they were underrepresented in all past studies. Also more research and dissemination of data are needed to support AN screening as a standard requirement for all school children.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Findings of this systematic review provide evidence to support AN as a reliable indicator for risk of type 2 diabetes in obese children and adolescents. School nurses, nurse practitioners, and primary care providers have a tremendous role in educating children and their parents about the risk factors for T2DM. Screening for AN in school children will open opportunities for patient education and parental involvement, including referral to primary care providers for further evaluation and management.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
